DOC.HEAD: Thousands Pour Through Newly Opened Brandenburg Gate
RETRANSMITTING to indicate 1st Ld-Writethru
Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE thousands pouring into West Berlin for last-minute Christmas shopping. Pickup 7th, `West German Chancellor...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of East Berliners poured through new Berlin Wall border crossings at the Brandenburg Gate today for a final, frantic day of Christmas shopping in the well-stocked stores of the West. Other Berliners headed for home after singing and dancing late into the night at the newly opened gate, which has been transformed from a symbol of Germany's divisions into one of East-West rapprochement. Although visa-free travel for West Germans to East Germany technically does not take effect until Sunday, there were few formalities at the Brandenburg Gate, opened only Friday, for those who headed East today. Throughout the night Friday, a steady clink of metal against stone accompanied the merrymakers as hundreds of souvenir seekers chipped away at the Berlin Wall near the gate in the 28-year-old Berlin Wall. At other crossing points, East German shoppers laden with purchases from West Berlin carried Christmas presents, cases of beer and bags of oranges. West German television periodically carried live coverage of the festivities Friday night, showing the crowd dancing on top of the wall, popping champagne corks and waving sparklers. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Premier Hans Modrow met Friday for the second time in a week at a ceremony formally opening two border crossings in the wall just north and south of the towering gate. Security collapsed as soon as the two crossings were opened. Thousands of people pushed down metal barriers erected to control the crowd and swept through the vast Paris square, snaking through the gate and climbing the wall. West Berlin police estimated that more than 30,000 people had gathered on the Western side for the ceremony. The crowd on the Eastern side appeared to be much larger, but there were no official estimates. Although more than 20 border crossings have been cut through the Berlin Wall since East Germany opened its borders to the West on Nov. 9, the opening of the Brandenburg Gate was the emotional climax of the rapid merger of the people divided since the end of World War II. The openings resulted from a popular uprising in East Germany that drove out its hard-line Communist leaders. When the Berlin Wall was built in 1961, the Brandenburg Gate, Berlin's most famous landmark that straddled a main prewar thoroughfare, remained in the East. It was also inaccessible to East Berliners until Friday because it was part of the off-limit East German border zone. The crowd carried Berlin, West German and East German flags. One large sign saying in English ``Come Together'' was held aloft by several people who climbed atop the wall. The thick section of the wall directly in front of the gate remains, but hundreds climbed on top to dance and hug in joyful scenes reminiscent of the time when the borders were first opened in November. Kohl said the opening of the gate was a ``fantastic thing.'' He and Modrow met Friday afternoon on the border line, shook hands and then walked together to a platform to address the crowd. The two leaders were nearly mobbed by the exultant crowd as security officials tried in vain to establish some control. The ceremony was broadcast live on both countries' national television. ``This is where the heart of Berlin pounds,'' said a commentator for West Germany's ZDF network. Modrow reminded the crowd of the role the gate has played in German history, then said its new function should be ``to serve the peace.'' Kohl said, ``This is the happiest day in my life, because I feel that here in Berlin I am standing in the middle of Germany.'' ``We need the sympathy, the support and the approval of our neighbors'' as the two Germanys move closer together, he said. ``We want peace and freedom.'' The speeches were drowned out by the noisy crowd. Many people had tears in their eyes as they mingled together. ``Berlin, have fun now,'' West Berlin mayor Walter Momper told the crowd.
